awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Development of lignin-based biodegradable plastic alloys via solvent free reactive extrusion
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will demonstrate the ability to create a new family of biobased and biodegradable polymers produced from agricultural and forestry waste streams that have the potential to mitigate landfill-bound, single-use plastics prevalent in agricultural operations. In conventional agricultural operations, farmers use plastic mulch films to block weeds and retain moisture in the soil, ultimately increasing crop yields. Unfortunately, the non-degradable plastics that are used must be removed after harvest and sent to a landfill as they are not recyclable due to contamination by soil and pesticides, leading to significant labor and disposal costs and increasing environmental burden. In this project, lignin polymer alloys are investigated as an innovative biodegradable plastic platform which can be used as an alternative to conventional materials that are not recyclable. Agriculture films represent a global market of $2.5 billion. Other attractive market opportunities include agricultural containers ($5 billion), garbage bags ($10 billion), and packaging ($115 billion). Lignin as a renewable feedstock is an excellent candidate for low cost, biodegradable plastics. Successful demonstration of commercial-scale uses for lignin is vital for the emerging biorefinery industry, and a primary task to secure the energy and materials future for the US.

The intellectual merit of this project addresses the need for low-cost, biobased plastics to replace petroleum derived materials, while ensuring a closed-loop lifecycle that does not generate financial and environmental burden due to waste accumulation. To date, lignin-based polymers have been prohibitively expensive due to the need for extensive solvent-based modification and separations processes. The objective of this research project is to demonstrate the production of lignin-polymer alloys with: 1) unmodified lignin contents of 50% or higher through solvent-free, high shear melt processing; 2) enhanced interfacial surface area for material durability; 3) mechanical properties near or exceeding that of low-density polyethylene; and 4) biodegradability under both ambient soil and thermophilic composting conditions. The expected technical results will be production of at least 1 optimal formulation meeting the above conditions identified as suitable for use in agricultural mulch film applications. If all 4 of these are achieved, further research in a subsequent Phase II award will allow for demonstration of scaled manufacturing of this new family of sustainable biomaterials and has the potential to lead to some of the first commercially viable lignin-based plastics in the US for use in agricultural plastic applications and beyond.

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project was performed to demonstrate the ability to create a new family of biobased and biodegradable polymers produced from agricultural and forestry waste streams that have the potential to mitigate landfill-bound, single-use plastics prevalent in agricultural operations. In conventional agricultural operations, farmers use plastic mulch films to block weeds and retain moisture in the soil, ultimately increasing crop yields. Unfortunately, the non-degradable plastics that are used must be removed after harvest and sent to a landfill as they are not recyclable due to contamination by soil and pesticides, leading to significant labor and disposal costs and increasing environmental burden. In this proposal, lignin polymer alloys are investigated as an innovative biodegradable plastic platform which can be used as an alternative to conventional materials that are not recyclable. Agriculture films represent a global market of $2.5 billion. Other attractive market opportunities include agricultural containers ($5 billion), garbage bags ($10 billion), and packaging ($115 billion). Lignin as a renewable feedstock is an excellent candidate for low cost, biodegradable plastics. Successful demonstration of commercial-scale uses for lignin is vital for the emerging biorefinery industry, and a primary task to secure the energy and materials future of the U.S.

 

Grow Bioplastics, LLC characterized over 15 different lignin samples from a variety of biomass feedstocks and extraction processes, with the goal of identifying several suitable for use in a reactive extrusion process to produce bio-based and bio-degradable plastics with a minimum of 50% unmodified lignin contents, ability to withstand high-shear melt processing, mechanical properties similar to Low Density Polyethylene, and the ability to degrade in ambient soil and thermophilic composting conditions. We identified six lignin samples in this process that were capable of meeting the above conditions, including samples from hardwood trees, softwood trees, and corn stover - an agricultural crop residue. Using these lignins, we evaluated over 80 formulations of lignin, bioplastic, and catalyst under a range of processing conditions. We were able to identify two functional catalysts and a range of usable formulations with lignin contents between 40 and 60%.

 

Additionally, we were able to make determinations about the purity of the lignin that can be used in our process, and the tolerance ranges of bound cellulose and hemicellulose. During different pulping or biomass fractionation processes, lignin is either enzymatically or thermochemically removed from cellulose and hemicellulose. These cellulose and hemicellulose products are eventually converted into paper and pulp products, or further processed into sugars to produce biofuels and bioproducts. As part of this separation process, some hemicellulose and cellulose is still chemically bound to the lignin material. From our initial results, we have identified that our process can tolerate bound carbohydrate contents as high as 10%. We believe with further study, we may be able to increase this number.

 

Our biodegradation and composting studies are ongoing, as these tests require 6 to 24 months of repeatable data. We are evaluating eight different formulations of our final materials, based on two different lignin types, two different copolymers, and a single catalyst. We plan to incorporate this degradation data into a Phase II application. Future work for this material will include demonstration of continuous production using twin-screw extrusion equipment common to the plastics compounding industry, as well as field applications on the form of thin plastic mulch films, and thermoformed plastic containers like flower and tree pots for the horticulture and nursery industries.
